News.title: Five unanswered questions in Emile Soleil murder riddle from crucial 15 mins before vanishing to sudden mass DNA test
News.content:
EMILE MYSTERY Five unanswered questions in Emile Soleil murder riddle from crucial 15 mins before vanishing to sudden mass DNA test

MAJOR questions still hang over the death of toddler Emile Soleil more than two years after he disappeared.

The two-year-old vanished from his grandparents’ isolated holiday home in the French Alps on July 8, 2023 – and was found dead 266 days later.





His remains, including a fractured skull, were discovered in March 2024 by a rambler just 25 minutes from the Alpine hamlet of Haut-Vernet, south of Grenoble.

Prosecutors say he suffered “violent facial trauma” and claim his body was moved after death.

Now, with locals reportedly being asked to give DNA samples in a huge new testing drive, five huge questions still hang over the case.



Why DNA testing three years after disappearance?

In a dramatic new development, cops have launched a mass DNA testing effort in Haut-Vernet.

Around 100 villagers will reportedly have samples taken as detectives hunt what they believe could be the toddler’s killer.

Emile’s grandparents, Philippe and Anne Vedovini, both 59, had their DNA taken at the start of the investigation.

Investigators have revealed the body had been moved when the child was already dead.



Even more chillingly, Emile had not died in the clothes he was wearing when he was discovered.

Public prosecutor Jean-Luc Blachon said: “These elements allow us to consider that the body did not remain in the same place and in the same biotope during the decomposition process.”

The decomposition reportedly suggests the body may have been preserved in a protected environment, such as a freezer.

The fact his remains were found in an area already thoroughly searched has fuelled claims someone brought him back.

Is the DNA sweep a sign detectives believe the answer lies within the tiny Alpine community?



Why were grandparents arrested?

Emile’s grandparents were dramatically arrested in dawn raids along with two of their adult children – identified as the boy’s aunt and uncle.

All four faced charges of ‘intentional homicide’ and ‘concealing a corpse’, according to a statement from Aix-an-Provence prosecutors.



They were quizzed for 17 hours but later released.

Lead prosecutor Jean-Luc Bachon said the charges were “not sufficient to warrant an indictment”.

He added that all four had answered questions “put to them”.

Enquiry sources confirmed the grandparents were detained following months of police wire taps.

Conversations between them and other family members were secretly listened to.



Philippe Vedovini is also under investigation in an entirely separate case relating to alleged sexual abuse at a Roman Catholic school in the 1990s.

He has always denied the claims and insisted he did nothing wrong.

Why did priest who baptised Emile ‘die by suicide’?

In another shocking twist, Father Claude Gilliot, who baptised Emile, allegedly died by suicide in recent weeks.

The 85-year-old reportedly left a suicide note when he was found after “a massive overdose”, according to an investigation source.

The priest had been close to Emile’s grandparents but is believed to have fallen out with them in recent years.



He even provided a photo of Emile to the media when the boy was missing – only to be condemned by the family.

The Vedovini family later boycotted his chapel.

His death has stunned locals, as under Catholic teaching, suicide is viewed as a mortal sin on par with murder.

Police have not publicly linked his death to the investigation.

Why was Emile left alone before disappearance?

On the day he vanished, Emile was last seen with his grandfather.



Philippe later admitted he had left the toddler alone in the garden during what he described as “fifteen minutes of inattention”.

Two witnesses claimed they saw the child wandering alone while Philippe was chopping wood.

A source close to the investigation told La Depeche the pair who “confirmed that they saw the child walking alone at the time of his disappearance” are “reliable people” who they “trust completely”.

Emile was wearing a yellow top, white shorts with a green pattern, and hiking shoes.

His parents were not in the village at the time.



Why did it take 266 days to find remains?

Emile’s remains were discovered 266 days after he vanished – in an area already searched by cops, soldiers, sniffer dogs, volunteers, helicopters and drones.

How was he not found sooner?



Prosecutors confirmed the remains had been moved just before they were discovered.

Blachon also said Emile’s body did not decompose in the clothes he was found in.

Locals previously floated a wolf attack theory.

One person told Le Parisien at the time: “The little one must have been the victim of an animal. And I only see the wolf as the culprit.

“They say wolves are afraid of people, but with a little boy like that, a big boy, the wolf would have seen him as another prey.”



François Balique, the mayor of Vernet, also reportedly appeared to believe the theory.

But the evidence now appears to point elsewhere.

It comes as disturbing background details about the family have also emerged.

Emile’s father, Colomban, was arrested in 2018 over an alleged “attack on foreigners” before being released after agreeing to maintain the peace.

He was reportedly linked to Action Francaise and the neofascist Bastion Social.



Three years later, he and Emile’s mother stood in a local election and were said to support Éric Zemmour.

Meanwhile, Philippe Vedovini was previously implicated as an “assisted witness” in an enquiry into alleged abuse at the Riaumont boarding school in Pas-de-Calais.

In 2018, he admitted to administering “somewhat harsh” physical discipline but has always denied breaking the law.

RECOMMENDED STORIES

Despite the arrests, the raids, the wire taps and now the sweeping DNA dragnet, no one has been charged over Emile’s death.

The investigation continues.

News.title: At least one dead & 39 injured after tram derails in Milan and smashes into store leaving passengers trapped
News.content:
AT least one person is dead and 39 injured after a tram derailed in Milan and smashed into a store.

The tram was heading for Porta Genova when it came off the tracks on Via Vitto Veneto at about 4pm local time.





After detaching from the track, the vehicle smashed into a shop window, crushing one person to death.

The victim was reportedly trapped under the tram’s wheels.

Passengers heard a terrifying noise that sounded like an “earthquake” from underneath the tram, before it veered off, gathering speed and crashing into the building.



One on board told ANSA: “I thought it was an earthquake. I was sitting and I fell to the ground, along with the other passengers. It was terrible.

“The man next to me was bleeding from his head. It took me a while to get up and get off.”

Another passenger said: “We heard something down below, then the tram derailed, and we were all thrown around. The tram veered, picked up speed, and hit a building.”

It is not yet known why the tram came off the tracks near the centre of the northern Italian city, which is currently hosting its Fashion Week, although reports have suggested the tram took a sharp turn too quickly.



Emergency medical services, including six ambulances and a medic car, scrambled to the scene.

Firefighters managed to extract passengers from inside the tram. Their conditions are currently unclear.

Civil protection teams have set up a tent to assist the injured.

Authorities have launched a probe to investigate the cause of the tragedy.

The incident involved a Tramlink tram, which can carry a maximum of 66 passengers.



Stretching to 82 ft long, the trams consist of three connecting carriages.

They form a new fleet purchased by local transport company ATM, which has invested £160million.



A total of 74 Tramlink trams entered service in Milan on February 20.

They are expected to replace the older trams over the next two years.

ATM has not made an immediate comment.

It came after a tragic funicular crash hit another European city last year.



Tragedy struck the Portuguese capital of Lisbon when its famous funicular derailed while packed full of passengers on September 3 2025, killing 16.

The Gloria Funicular – one of the Portuguese capital’s most iconic attractions – came off its tracks after a cable reportedly came loose.

The tram sped down the street out of control before smashing into the building on the bend at full speed and seemingly without brakes.

Witnesses described the car crumpling like a “cardboard box” when it hit the wall.

Dozens sprinted up the steep road to find the car had flipped on its side and was torn apart into splintered metal.



Distressed onlookers can be heard screaming “there’s kids under there” seconds after the cable car with tourists on board derailed and smashed into a hotel.

RECOMMENDED STORIES

Three Brits were among the 16 victims, while another 20 were injured.

A report into the crash details a litany of failures and noted that the underground cable was defective and had never been certified for passenger transportation.

News.title: Fergie 'being supported' by unlikely allies in Andrew crisis as 'dual personality' exposed
News.content:
EXCLUSIVE: Fergie 'being supported' by unlikely allies in Andrew crisis as 'dual personality' exposed

Sarah Ferguson has not been seen in public in six months, and a royal expert suspects she is being supported by some of her most powerful and wealthy allies

Sarah Ferguson continues to keep a very low profile following the shocking Epstein revelations - and could be receiving support from a network of powerful allies.

‌



The former Duchess of York has not been seen in public for the last six months, in which time she and her ex-husband were stripped of their titles and right to live at Royal Lodge after documents from the Jeffrey Epstein files revealed the extent of their relationship with the late paedophile.

‌



Fergie, 66, was reportedly spotted at a wellness retreat in Donegal, Ireland, last month and there is speculation that she recently visited the United Arab Emirates and one of the world's priciest health resorts in Switzerland, but her exact whereabouts is currently unknown.

‌



View 3 Images Fergie's whereabouts is currently unknown, while Andrew has moved to Sandringham (Image: PA Archive/PA Images)

According to royal expert Ingrid Seward, Fergie may well have fled the UK to seek solace at one of the homes of her many wealthy friends around the world.

"Nobody knows where she is at this moment, I mean she could be anywhere, she could be in Dummer with her stepmother, or she could be abroad," she told the Mirror.

‌



"She's got some rich and powerful friends who probably will stick by her, because we know rich and powerful people like drama, and this is a great drama, isn’t it?".

Fergie's father and stepmother, Major Ronald and Susan Ferguson, moved to Dummer village, near Basingstoke in Hampshire when she was a child. She later said she grew up "loving the oak trees" around their home, and they were the inspiration for her 2020 children's book, The Enchanted Oak Tree.

View 3 Images Sarah and Andrew opened the Dummer village fete in July 1989 (Image: Mirrorpix)

‌



Documents released from the Epstein files included several email exchanges between Fergie and Epstein, who was found dead in his jail cell in 2019, and showed that their friendship lasted longer than she had previously claimed.

It also emerged that she had discussed meeting up with Epstein for lunch - with daughters Princess Beatrice and Princess Eugenie - shortly after he was released from prison in 2009 for soliciting sex from underage girls.

According to Ingrid, who has known Fergie since before she married Andrew in 1986, there is every chance she is still hoping the situation will blow over and she can return to something resembling her old life.

‌



"She has a massively endearing type of personality," she said. "It's a tragedy that her bad side has got the stronger hold over her than her good side. So the bad side is the greed, the stupidity and obsessively wanting things. She desperately, desperately wants to be liked."

View 3 Images Sarah described sex trafficker Epstein as 'the brother I have always wished for' in one exchange (Image: AP)

She continued, "[She has] an inability to connect with reality - but I suppose she’s connecting with reality now - or maybe she’s not. Maybe she’s literally got her head in the sand thinking, 'this will all go away'. And it’s not impossible in a way, if Andrew isn’t convicted of a crime."

Article continues below

Fergie's ex Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, meanwhile, has been keeping less of a low profile and has been photographed in public a number of times over the last month, including on one occasion while he was horse riding in the grounds around Royal Lodge, shortly before his eviction. He was also seen on the day of his arrest by Thames Valley Police on suspicion of misconduct in public office.

The former Duke of York spent 11 hours in custody at Aylsham police station in Norfolk on what was his 66th birthday - February 18 - and was photographed looking somewhat dishevelled in the backseat of a car as he was driven back to Sandringham.

News.title: Soham murderer Ian Huntley 'knew he was a target' before horror metal bar attack in jail
News.content:
EXCLUSIVE: Soham murderer Ian Huntley 'knew he was a target' before horror metal bar attack in jail

Ian Huntley "knew he was a target" in HMP Frankland before being attacked with a metal bar earlier this week, as the paranoid Soham murderer still fights for life

View 7 Images Ian Huntley after being treated in 2005 (Image: Daily Mirror)

Ian Huntley was paranoid about his food as he was expecting an attack in prison, it's been revealed.

‌



The Soham murderer "knew he was a target", a source told the Mirror, and was carefully watching what he was eating out of fear of being poisoned.

‌



Huntley remained in a serious condition today after an inmate battered him around the head with a metal bar. He was left in a pool of blood in a workshop at HMP Frankland on Thursday morning.

‌



Police and prison authorities have not confirmed the identity of the suspect, named as triple killer Anthony Russell. Huntley, who worked as a cleaner on A wing at Frankland, had given up prison food because he was so convinced his fellow inmates were "out to get him."

He had been attacked before at Frankland, and HMP Wakefield, where he also attempted to take his own life in 2005.

View 7 Images Ian Huntley after a failed suicide bid in Wakefield jail in 2005 (Image: Daily Mirror)

‌



Ensure our latest headlines always appear at the top of your Google Search by making us a Preferred Source. Click here to activate or add us as your Preferred Source in your Google search settings

"He knew that he was a target," a source said. "That is why he was so paranoid about his food."

He bought fast food and confectionery from the shop, causing his weight to balloon. "He has been living on a diet of things like cheesy Wotsits," they added.

‌



"He would not eat the prison food because he was convinced an inmate would poison him. So he bought snack food from the shop so he knew exactly what he was eating."

Durham Police said there has been no change in the 52-year-old’s condition overnight. "He remains in hospital in a serious condition," said their spokesperson.

View 7 Images Huntley was attacked on Thursday morning (Image: Unknown)

‌



Huntley is serving a life sentence for the murders of 10-year-olds Holly Wells and Jessica Chapman after they left a family barbecue to buy sweets in Soham, Cambridgeshire, on August 4 2002.

He dumped their bodies in a ditch and fell under suspicion after giving media interviews about the police investigation. He is serving a minimum 40-year term and has become an increasingly isolated figure behind bars.

View 7 Images Anthony Russell reportedly attacked Ian Huntley at HMP Frankland (Image: West Midlands Police)

‌



"He does not look like the man we saw on TV all those years ago," the source added. "He is much, much heavier, his weight has ballooned because of his diet." Huntley, like many long term prisoners, had tried various ploys to improve his regime.

He worked as a cleaner on the wing so that staff could closely monitor him. He is held alongside others at risk of attack and kept apart from the rest of the prison population. But his attacker struck "when it was least expected", according to insiders.

View 7 Images Durham's Frankland jail (Image: PA)

‌



"Huntley's wing is like a prison within a prison," they added. "Some inmates there convert to Islam because the food is meant to be better. They also think the regime allows more time out of the cell to pray. They say the food is like having a takeaway."

Huntley was attacked with a 'heavy metal bar' just after 9am on Thursday. He was battered so violently around the head that there were fears for his life. He has been attacked three times while behind bars and has twice attempted suicide.

View 7 Images Huntley was jailed for the murders of Holly Wells and Jessica Chapman in 2002 (Image: Shutterstock)

‌



The bodies of Holly Wells and Jessica Chapman were found two weeks after they disappeared in August 2002.

Huntley was convicted in December 2003 following a trial at the Old Bailey. His girlfriend Maxine Carr, a teaching assistant at the girls' primary school, was also jailed in 2003 after being found guilty of conspiring to pervert the course of justice.

View 7 Images Police sealed off Huntley's home, which he shared with Maxine Carr (Image: PA)

Article continues below

She was freed from jail and given a new identity in May 2004. After his arrest, it emerged Huntley had been able to work with children despite facing rape and sexual assault complaints.

He had been the subject of a series of allegations made to police in Humberside, where he previously worked. A subsequent inquiry led to criminal checks on anyone working with children.

Huntley was scalded with boiling water at HMP Wakefield in 2005. He was moved to Frankland, where robber Damien Fowkes slashed him in 2010. The wound was 7in (18cm) long and required 21 stitches. Fowkes asked a prison officer: "Is he dead? I hope so."

News.title: Bake Off's Prue Leith, 86, admits 'I don't have long left' in sad dying confession
News.content:
EXCLUSIVE: Bake Off's Prue Leith, 86, admits 'I don't have long left' in sad dying confession

National treasure Prue Leith sits down with the Mirror for a candid chat about living life well in old age, being a rotten grandparent - and her hopes of a good death

Exclusive: Dame Prue Leith reveals her best tips on ageing in her new book

Famed for her frankness, former Great British Bake Off judge, Dame Prue Leith has a confession. She says: “I think I was a good mum. I've been a rotten grandmother though.” Even since her decision to quit the ever popular Channel 4 show last month after nine years, she says: “I still don’t spend enough time with them. When I look at my fellow grandmothers, they live for their grandchildren. They shower them with attention, remembering all their birthdays. I fail utterly.

‌



"What do I bring to the table? Occasionally I give the children cooking lessons. My husband has a great method of attracting them to our house - he buys really dangerous toys, trikes, motorbikes, no stabilisers. They come for the danger… and stay for us - and lunch.”

‌



Now 86, Dame Prue has five grandchildren, 11 if combined with those of her husband, John Playfair, 72, who she met in 2011 and married in 2016. She has two children, a biological son, Danny Kruger, 51, and an adopted daughter from Cambodia, Li-Da Kruger, 50, from her marriage to her first husband, Rayne Kruger. They were together for 30 years before his death, aged 80, in 2002.

‌



Never before seen intimate pictures of Lorraine Kelly as her daughter opens up family album READ MORE :

She is now “very much in love and happily married” to retired fashion designer and tailor John and discusses their romance and more in her new book, Being Old and Learning to Love it, which is out now. She says: “I’d be quite happy to talk about love in old age, if I could keep some of it private. But, inevitably, people want to know about sex. How many times a year, a month? I’m not careful, I'm very indiscreet and my instinct is to tell anyone anything they want to know. But I get myself into trouble. I’m so egotistical!”

View 6 Images Alison Hammond, Noel Fielding, Prue Leith and Paul Hollywood (Image: Channel 4 / Love Productions)

As well as brushing up on her grandparenting skills, Dame Prue is keen to spend plenty of time holidaying, now she’s quit Bake Off. She says: “One of the chief reasons I gave up is because it’s filmed in the summer. I want a European summer holiday. I’m South African, I have to get near the sun. I’ve had lovely holidays in Africa, Australia. But I suddenly realised I might never have another holiday in Spain, or Italy, France, or Greece. I’ve cajoled the whole family to come away with me this summer.”

‌



One family member unlikely to be invited is her new Main Coon cat called Sophisticat, or Sophie for short. Displaying hands that have been scratched to pieces, she laughs: “My birthday present from John. I’ve got a kitten now who is an escape artist, and has the sharpest claws in the world and loves to play. I’m completely shredded.

“I’ve been texting Paul Hollywood non stop because he and his wife Mellissa have two Maine Coon cats too. He was the only person I told [she was leaving]. We’re such good friends and we’ve been a double act all this time - he needed to know first.”

6 View 6 Images Prue Leith and John Playfair (Image: Getty Images for Pimm's) 6 View 6 Images Cook, writer and broadcaster Prue Leith (2nd-L), with daughter Li-Da Kruger (L), her son Danny Kruger and his wife Emma pose after she became a Commander of the British Empire (CBE) (Image: Getty Images)

‌



Remaining in constant contact with Paul, she has been touched by the positive reaction to her departure. She says: “Nobody has said ‘good riddance’ - not one person! It’s extraordinary - it’s a cake show for goodness sake. There have been waves and waves of distress at my leaving, which is complete nonsense.”

Very fond of her replacement, Nigella Lawson, 66, she says: “She’s terrific.” But Dame Prue, who invites film crews into her Cotswolds home for the popular ITV show Prue Leith’s Cotswold Kitchen, is not retiring yet. She says: “I love filming at home - I barely need to get out of bed,” quips Prue. “And I get to spend time with John, who tells me I’m too busy and never stop, which to some extent is true. I do like being busy.”

Dressed in characteristically colourful bold striped trousers and matching specs, she adds: “My husband buys all my clothes. He’s got great taste.” With her inspiring joie de vivre, fans may be surprised to hear that, at any given moment, Dame Prue is probably thinking about death. She says: “I think about death a lot. I look ahead and see death. Funnily enough I think it’s something that old people do.

‌



View 6 Images Prue with late husband Rayne and adopted daughter Li-Da (Image: Prue Leith)

“I never thought about it in my 60s, but now it pops into my head most days. Just passing thoughts. The world is going to hell in a hand cart. Either AI will see us off, or war. I was born during the Second World War, and when it stopped we had 70/80 years of peace. But I think, ‘Oh well I won't be here - let them carry on.’ It’s quite comforting - I won't have to worry about that. I don’t have long left. Ten years if I’m lucky. I need to use them well.”

A keen advocate for assisted dying, while she is still “relatively healthy,” to the horror of her MP son, she has decided exactly how she’d like to go. She says: “I would like to go in my bed, surrounded by my family, at a time of my choosing. “When I’ve had enough, I just want to be able to take some drug, have someone inject me with something or other, and plan it.

‌



“I want to be ready, I won't be frightened, my family will know what I’m doing, there will be no surprises, nobody is going to have to find me dead in a heap or something. I’m up against some really strong opposition. My son leads the opposition. And he’s an incredibly formidable opponent. But I think assisted dying, while it might sound extreme, is sensible. A lot of people have an absolutely horrible death, and unnecessarily so.”

6 View 6 Images The Mirror's Hannah Britt meets Prue Leith 6 View 6 Images Hannah and Prue

‌



She blames opposition to choosing when to die on serial killer Harold Shipman. She says: “Harold Shipman - I bet you didn’t think we’d be talking about him this afternoon - changed everything, because he killed a lot of old ladies. But it’s possible to have a good death. Lots of countries have passed this law and nobody has ever tried to rescind it. Four per cent of people in Canada are dying now in this way, and I think it's proof that it’s a popular bill. I wouldn't be surprised if it was 50% when word gets around how much nicer it is. I feel quite strongly about it.”

Yet, despite all the talk of death, Prue isn’t planning to go quite yet. In fact, she isn’t even considering settling into her dotage. She says: “I don’t like the word ‘retire’. But then I have always loved to work. Though I’m rather hoping this book will be my last. It’s amazing to be 86. It’s a vast old age and I’m quite astonished to be there. People think of old age as such a tragedy. But, honestly, for a lot of people it’s just like the rest of life.

“I have no reason to be unhappy. If I wasn’t happy I think it would be disgracefully ungrateful, because I have all the things that make you happy. I’m comparatively healthy for my age. I sleep well. I eat well. I love well. I’ve had two happy marriages and the second one is still going strong. Both my children are fine, all my grandchildren are healthy. I’ve had a successful career. What is there to complain about? Nothing.”

Article continues below

*Being Old and Learning to Love it by Prue Leith, published by Short Books £20, is out now

News.title: Keir Starmer 'wake up call' as Labour reels after nightmare by-election loss
News.content:
Keir Starmer 'wake up call' as Labour reels after nightmare by-election loss

The loss of the Gorton and Denton by-election triggered a wave of Labour anger as the party sank to third - sparking calls to treat the defeat as a 'wake up call'

View 3 Images Prime Minister Keir Starmer is facing up to a disastrous defeat (Image: PA)

Keir Starmer has been urged to treat Labour's by-election nightmare as a "wake up call" after the Greens pulled off a major upset in a seat it has held for nearly 100 years.

‌



Labour was relegated to third place in Gorton and Denton as Green candidate Hannah Spencer stormed to victory with 14,980 votes - a majority of 4,402. Hard-right Reform candidate Matt Goodwin came second on 10,578 votes, followed by Labour's Angeliki Stogia on 9,364.

‌



The victory - the Greens' first ever in a parliamentary by-election - triggered a wave of Labour anger as the party failed to defend a seat it won with a 13,413-vote majority in 2024. And there were recriminations over the decision by Labour chiefs to block Andy Burnham from standing in the race.

‌



Key Green Party policies from drugs, Gaza and pay to scrapping nuclear weapons READ MORE :

View 3 Images Hannah Spencer became the Green Party's fifth MP in the Commons (Image: Getty Images)

Mr Starmer struck a defiant tone, saying he would fight "for as long as I've got breath in my body" to help those who need change. But ex-Deputy PM Angela Rayner said the by-election defeat must be a “wake up call” for the Government. "It's time to really listen - and to reflect," she said.

"Voters want the change that we promised - and they voted for. If we want to unrig the system, if we want to make the change we were sent into Government to make, we have to be braver.

‌



"A Labour agenda that puts people first." Joanne Thomas, General Secretary of Usdaw, a union usually loyal to Mr Starmer, urged the Government to learn lessons.

"A majority of voters there do not feel that the Labour Government is providing the change they need, or the change the Labour Party committed to at the General Election," she said.

View 3 Images Angela Rayner said the result must be a wake-up call (Image: Getty Images)

‌



"I hope the Government reflects seriously on how it can regain that trust." Others went further, with Fire Brigades Union chief Steve Wright saying the party risked heavy losses at the May elections if it failed to "change course immediately".

Labour MP Karl Turner, who has been critical of the PM's approach to criminal justice, said the result was “catastrophic”. He added: “Frankly the fact that Andy Burnham was blocked, who was the candidate who gave us our best chance, that's why we are where we are."

The Prime Minister described the result as "very disappointing" - but insisted he understood voters' frustration. He dismissed questions over whether he would resign, saying: "I came into politics late in life to fight for change for those people who need it. "I will keep on fighting for those people for as long as I've got breath in my body."

‌



The PM also pledged to "fight against extremes in politics" on both sides that threatened to "tear our country apart." In a letter to Labour MPs, Mr Starmer ramped up his attacks on Zack Polanski's party.

He said: “We will continue to warn of the risk the Greens pose: the risk of extreme policies like legalising all drugs and pulling out of Nato that most voters strongly reject, and the risk of splitting the progressive vote so that Reform come through the middle.” Behind the scenes, there was real fury over the Green victory.

A Government source told the Mirror : “They are the new Lib Dems. Shape-shifting snake oil merchants playing opposition politics." The source also called for cool heads in Labour, saying: "This is going to have an impact, of course, but we can’t view everything through the prism of one by-election."

‌



Meanwhile, Downing Street rebuffed calls to dramatically change course and said Labour must deliver for "mainstream Britain". A No10 source said: “We have a progressive manifesto which is popular with the public and we need to get on with the delivery. It’s not about copying the Greens platform.

“There is always a problem in Government that there are distractions. But there is a meaty agenda that we need to shout about. “The most important thing is the cost of living and we have to keep going at that really hard rather than giving up to go down another alley."

The source added: “We have the Greens on one extreme and Reform on the other. We have a real opportunity to deliver for mainstream Britain.” Ms Spencer, who works as a plumber, offered an apology to her customers after she was elected as the Greens fifth MP.

Article continues below

In her victory speech, she joked: "I think I might have to cancel the work that you had booked in, because I'm heading to Parliament. And when I get there, I will make space for everyone doing jobs like mine, we will finally get a seat at the table."

The 34-year-old pledged to help those struggling with the cost of living as she said working hard "used to get you something. She said: "Instead of working for a nice life, we're working to line the pockets of billionaires. We are being bled dry.

"And I don't think it's extreme or radical to think working hard should get you a nice life."

News.title: Putin's gymnast lover 'handed £63million in leftover funds from dictator's £1billion palace'
News.content:
Putin's gymnast lover 'handed £63million in leftover funds from dictator's £1billion palace'

A huge billion-pound construction project to create Putin's palace getaway home ended up with tens of million in surplus cash - an investigation claimed this was all given to the despot's lover

View 3 Images Putin and his 'secret lover' Alina Kabaeva (Image: Kremlin.ru/e2w)

Vladimir Putin's lover, and reportedly mum to two of his children, was handed a huge £63million in leftover cash from the construction of a palace for the despot, it's been claimed.

‌



Former Olympic gymnast Alina Kabaeva, 42 and three decades his junior, has been rumoured to be in a relationship with the evil dictator since 2008. The ex athlete, now a Russian politician, supposedly has two boys with the despot - Ivan, 11, and Vladimir, six - but neither have confirmed their relationship.

‌



A luxury palace, in the southern town Gelendzhik, was first uncovered back in 2021 but Putin and the Kremlin have denied the billion-pound mansion belongs to the warmonger. The property is officially owned by a firm named 'Investment Solutions' - with it's shareholders being three of Putin's closest associates.

‌

View 3 Images Putin's £1 million palace at Gelendzhik on the Black Sea (Image: Alexei Navalny/e2w)

The three men behind the company are businessman Ilham Rahimov, former classmate Viktor Khmarin and lawyer Nikolai Egorov. FBK, an organisation created by the late Putin opposition leader Alexei Navalny, said bank records revealed the company was sent loans from offshore entities - based in the British Virgin Islands.

‌



A new investigation has claimed leftover money from the palace construction project was sent to Putin's lover, in the form of donations to two of her charities, according to FBK.

When the palace was finished in 2023, a whopping 6.5billion rubles (£63million) was left over from the loans sent to build the property. A lump sum of 3billion rubles (£29million) was donated to the Alina Kabaeva Charitable Foundation immediately after the home was complete, according to the Daily Mail.

View 3 Images The pair allegedly have two kids together and have been in a quiet relationship for nearly two decades (Image: Kremlin.ru/e2w)

‌



This charity works to help female athletes and also helped to fix a church in occupied Crimea. The FBK however has claimed these projects only cost a fractions of the billions of rubles sent over, and claimed the rest was hidden away in a deposit account.

The other 3.5billion rubles (£34million) was allegedly sent to the gymnast's other charity called Heavenly Grace, according to the FBK investigation. This non-profit reportedly dished out £288,000 at the Imperial Peterhof luxury watch factory, per independent Russian news site Meduza.

FBK also claimed some of that cash was spent on gymnastics camps but the anti-Putin group claimed it was a shield to allow the couples alleged kids a chance to play with other kids. The group claimed that most of the millions sent to the charity were stashed away in deposit accounts, saying these donations were "slush funds" for Putin's secret lover.

Article continues below

Putin's £1billion clifftop palace, overlooking the Black Sea, has it's own church, ice rink, casino and hookah lounge. The massive getaway for the despot is even bigger than Buckingham Palace.

Leaked diagrams appeared to show the evil Russian leader had ordered tunnels which lie about 50 metres below the surface of his lair to be built. The underground complex reportedly spans a huge 6,500 square feet.

News.title: Artemis astronauts in NASA's shakeup as additional moon missions added
News.content:
Artemis astronauts in NASA's shakeup as additional moon missions added

NASA's Artemis III mission had been targeting a landing near the moon's south pole but there has been concern that it is overly ambitious with the space agency not ready

View 2 Images NASA's Artemis II at Kennedy Space Centre in Florida (Image: AFP via Getty Images)

NASA said it's adding an extra moon mission by Artemis astronauts before attempting a high-risk lunar landing with a crew.

‌



The shakeup in the flight line-up came just two days after NASA's new moon rocket returned to its hangar for more repairs and a safety panel warned the space agency to scale back its overly ambitious goals for humanity's first lunar landing in more than half a century.

‌



Artemis II - a lunar fly-around by four astronauts - is off until at least April because of rocket problems. The follow-up mission - Artemis III - had been targeting a landing near the moon's south pole by another pair of astronauts a year or two later.

‌



Ensure our latest headlines always appear at the top of your Google Search by making us a Preferred Source. Click here to activate or add us as your Preferred Source in your Google search settings.

View 2 Images An overhaul has been made of a lunar landing by NASA (Image: AFP via Getty Images)

But with concern growing over the readiness of a lunar lander and moonwalking suits and long gaps between flights, NASA's new administrator Jared Isaacman announced that mission would instead focus on launching a lunar lander into orbit around Earth for practice in 2027.

‌



The new plan calls for a moon landing - potentially even two moon landings - by astronauts in 2028. Isaacman stressed that three years between flights is unacceptable and that he'd like to get it down to one year or even less.

During NASA's storied Apollo programme, he said, astronauts' first flight to the moon was followed by two more missions before Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin landed on the moon.

Matalan store closures announced as more shops shut with 50% off sale READ MORE :

The Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel recommended this week that NASA revise its objectives for Artemis III "given the demanding mission goals." It's urgent the space agency do that, the panel said, if the United States hopes to safely return astronauts to the moon.

‌



A NASA statement on Artemis III had previously said: "After touchdown (on the moon), the surface crew’s first task will be to ensure all systems are ready for their lunar surface stay. Then they will rest, eat, and recharge for the first full day of the expedition.

"During their time on the moon, the astronauts will do scientific work inside Starship and conduct a series of moonwalks, exiting Starship to explore the surface.

"The astronauts will don advanced spacesuits, exit through an airlock, and descend on Starship’s elevator. NASA has selected Axiom Space to provide the Artemis III surface suits and spacewalk systems. These suits will give the astronauts increased range of motion and flexibility to explore more of the landscape than on previous lunar missions.

Article continues below

"During their moonwalks, the astronauts will take pictures and video, survey geology, retrieve samples, and collect other data to meet specific scientific objectives."

The former-US President was called to testify in front of a congressional panel ‌about his links to the late sex offender, where ex-Secretary of State Hillary also spoke yesterday. The ex-President has vehemently denied having any knowledge of Epstein's crimes.

News.title: 'Unbreakable' code baffled detectives investigating mystery of MI6 spy found dead in bag
News.content:
'Unbreakable' code baffled detectives investigating mystery of MI6 spy found dead in bag

MI6 prodigy Gareth Williams, 31, was found dead inside a padlocked bag in a Pimlico flat used to house intelligence workers - and new questions have been raised about the police's investigation

View 3 Images MI6 code breaker Gareth Williams, 31, was found dead inside a sports bag in his flat (Image: PA)

Detectives investigating the mysterious death of an MI6 spy mistakenly identified the name of a Welsh mountain as a secret code, it has been claimed.

‌



The decomposing body of the 31-year-old mathematics prodigy Gareth Williams was discovered padlocked inside a red North Face bag in the bathtub of his Pimlico flat in August 2010 - sparking a major investigation that saw Scotland Yard given unprecedented access to the secret services.

‌



During the investigation, officers searching Mr Williams' diary uncovered a jumbled phrase they believed to be an 'uncrackable' cipher that could offer key clues over the events leading up to his death.

‌



UK diplomats rushed out of base in Israel after Middle East security fears READ MORE :

View 3 Images A reconstruction of a man locking himself in a sports holdall was shown to the jury during the inquest (Image: PA)

Ensure our latest headlines always appear at the top of your Google Search by making us a Preferred Source. Click here to activate or add us as your Preferred Source in your Google search settings

‌



However, when they presented the note to the dead man's friends, it was quickly identified as 'Cadair Idris' - a mountain in Wales - written in his native Welsh . A source close to the family noted that Mr Williams was training for the Snowdon marathon at the time .

They described the error as one of several "embarrassing failures" in the police investigation, telling MailOnline: "That just shows you how useless they were" . Mr Williams was found naked inside the holdall, which had been fastened with a padlock from the outside, while the key was found underneath his body .

The flat, which is often used by intelligence staff, had the heating turned on full blast, despite it being the middle of summer, and there were no fingerprints found on the bag, padlock, or bath. In 2012, coroner Fiona Wilcox concluded that the death of Mr Williams, a GCHQ worker on secondment to MI6, was "unnatural and likely to have been criminally mediated" and that a third party may have been involved in moving the bag into the bath.

‌



View 3 Images CCTV image of Gareth Williams at Holland Park Tube station two days before his death (Image: PA)

But Scotland Yard concluded that Williams most likely died alone after accidentally locking himself inside the bag. A forensic review reopened in 2021 was closed in 2024, with police stating it identified no further lines of inquiry to disprove their main theory. To this day, critics cast doubt on the narrative that Mr Williams acted alone.

Confined space rescue specialist Peter Faulding claimed he had tried "300 times" to replicate locking the bag from the inside without leaving forensic traces and failed, calling the police's solo-death theory a "physical impossibility".

‌



He told the Mail: "My belief is that the bag was placed in the bath with Gareth dead already. Even if he could get in the bag, and even if he then padlocked it from the inside, there would be footprints and fingerprints all over the bath and the bag."

The Met Police told the Mirror today that while the force is not reopening the case, any new evidence will be reviewed by specialist detectives should it come to light, as is the case with all unexplained deaths.

A spokesperson said: “Our thoughts remain with Gareth’s family who continue to grieve his loss. Since 2010, we have carried out extensive enquiries into Gareth’s death which has seen officers collect and review a significant amount of material and statements.

Article continues below

“As part of our investigation, officers also conducted a three-year forensic review. This was a thorough and in-depth process, which concluded in 2024 and identified no further lines of enquiry.

“As with all unexplained deaths, any new information or evidence will be reviewed by specialist detectives should it come to light.”
